summary: Enhancement to page editing on the client s side to minimise the do not edit time
description: The status quo in page editing is as follows Clicking on edit makes the Server mark a wiki page as currently being edited for a certain time
This timer may be stopped by x minutes without any action
a save or cancel request from the edit page
nothing more

Now web surfers do not care about technological issues and are lazy so in the majority of cases the user would simply close the edit page or use a go back function of his web browser if he changed his mind and did not want to edit the page anymore
The problem arising is that on the server side the page is still marked as being edited for a potentially long time
In the meantime other users cannot really edit the page because they are being warned that someone else is editing it although this may not be true anymore
This would not be a big problem in a rarely visited wiki but it is a really big problem in a frequented wiki
Additionally it has been found that most of the page lockings occur due to spiders and spambots not users as such
My proposal is something like making the client have to send a ping from time to time so that if the page has been closed the ping is not sent anymore
adding onexit on handlers signalling a cancel action to the server
Of course it does not help against wiki spam but the do not edit time will be minimised
In a way it is comparable to greylisting in the e mail domain
You make the client tell repeatedly that its request is still valid
Fewest spiders or spambots will respond to that

summary: Password hash should be salted
description: The password hash is calculated as a direct SHA digest of the password
Unfortunately this means that it is vulnerable to brute force attacks there are many web sites which store SHA hashes of common passwords
The key space in most languages is pretty small
So the password should really be properly salted with preferably a long random string

description: useDocValuesAsStored Many times a value will be both stored true and SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME true which requires redundant data to be stored on disk

Since reading from SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME is both efficient and a common practice facets analytics streaming etc reading values from SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME when a stored version of the field does not exist would be a valuable disk usage optimization
The only caveat with this that I can see would be for SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME fields as they would always be returned sorted in the SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME approach

summary: Versioning optimistic locking
description: In order increase the ability of Solr to be used as a Technology Names database lots of concurrent inserts updates deletes and queries in the entire lifetime of the index instead of just a search index first everything indexed in one thread after only queries I would like Solr to support versioning to be used for optimistic locking
When my intent see SOLR is to update an existing document I will need to provide a version number equal to the version number I got when I fetched the existing document for update plus one
If this provided version number does not correspond to the newest version number of that document at the time of update plus one I will get a SIMPLECLASSNAME error
If it does correspond the document will be updated with the new one so that the newest version number of that document is NOW one higher than before the update
Correct but efficient concurrency handling
When my intent see SOLR is to insert a new document the version number provided will not be used instead a version number will be used
According to SOLR insert will only succeed if a document with the same value on SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME field does not already exist

In general when talking about different versions of the same document of course we need to be able to identify when a document is the same that per definition is when the values of the SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME fields are equal
The functionality provided by this issue is only really meaningfull when you run with updateLog activated
This issue might be solved more or less at the same time as SOLR and only one single SVN patch might be given to cover both issues

summary: Multiple Solr Cores remove static singleton
description: WHAT As of VERSIONNUMBER Solr only instantiates one SIMPLECLASSNAME which handles one Lucene index
This patch is intended to allow multiple cores in Solr which also brings multiple indexes capability
The patch file to grab is solr FILEPATH see MISC session below
WHY The current Solr practical wisdom is that one schema thus one index is most likely to accomodate your indexing needs using a filter to segregate documents if needed
If you really need multiple indexes deploy multiple web applications
There are a some use cases however where having multiple indexes or multiple cores through Solr itself may make sense
Multiple cores Deployment issues within some organizations where IT will resist deploying multiple web applications
Seamless schema update where you can create a new core and switch to it without starting stopping servers
Embedding Solr in your own application instead of raw Lucene and functionally need to segregate schemas collections
Multiple indexes Multiple language collections where each document exists in different languages analysis being language dependant
Having document types that have nothing or very little in common with respect to their schema their lifetime update frequencies or even collection sizes
HOW The best analogy is to consider that instead of deploying multiple web application you can have one web application that hosts more than one Solr core
The patch does not change any of the core logic nor the core code each core is configured behaves exactly as the one core in VERSIONNUMBER the various caches are per core so is the info bean registry
What the patch does is replace the SIMPLECLASSNAME singleton by a collection of cores all the code modifications are driven by the removal of the different singletons the config the schema the core
Each core is named and a static map keyed by name allows to easily manage them
You declare one servlet filter mapping per core you want to expose in the FILEPATH this allows easy to access each core through a different url

USAGE example web deployment patch installed Step java Durl WEBLINK jar FILEPATH FILEPATH METHODORVARIABLENAME Will index the documents in FILEPATH FILEPATH Step WEBLINK Will produce the statistics page from the admin servlet on core index documents Step WEBLINK Will produce the statistics page from the admin servlet on core index no documents Step java Durl WEBLINK jar FILEPATH ipod xml java Durl WEBLINK jar FILEPATH mon xml Adds the FILEPATH to index of core and the FILEPATH to the index of core running queries from the admin interface you can verify indexes have different content
USAGE Java code create a configuration SIMPLECLASSNAME config new SIMPLECLASSNAME FILEPATH create a schema SIMPLECLASSNAME schema new SIMPLECLASSNAME config FILEPATH create a core from the other

SIMPLECLASSNAME core new SIMPLECLASSNAME core path to index config schema Accessing a core SIMPLECLASSNAME core METHODORVARIABLENAME core PATCH MODIFICATIONS DETAILS per package METHODORVARIABLENAME The heaviest modifications are in SIMPLECLASSNAME SIMPLECLASSNAME
SIMPLECLASSNAME is the most obvious modification instead of a singleton there is a static map of cores keyed by names and assorted methods
To retain some compatibility the null named core replaces the singleton for the relevant methods for instance METHODORVARIABLENAME
One small constraint on the core name is they cannot contain or avoiding potential url file path problems
SIMPLECLASSNAME SIMPLECLASSNAME are now used to persist all configuration options that need to be quickly accessible to the various components
Most of these variables were static like those found in SIMPLECLASSNAME
Mimicking the intent of these static variables SIMPLECLASSNAME SIMPLECLASSNAME use public final members to expose them
SIMPLECLASSNAME inherits from Config which has been modified Config is now more strictly a dom document filled from some resource and methods to evaluate xpath expressions
Config also continues to be the classloader singleton that allows to easily instantiate classes located in the Solr installation directory

METHODORVARIABLENAME SIMPLECLASSNAME SIMPLECLASSNAME now get the SIMPLECLASSNAME passed as a parameter to init one might want to read some resources to initialize the factory and the config dir is in the config
This is partially redundant with the argument map though
METHODORVARIABLENAME SIMPLECLASSNAME takes the core as a constructor parameter
METHODORVARIABLENAME The test harness has been modified to expose the core it instantiates
METHODORVARIABLENAME SIMPLECLASSNAME is now instantiating a core configured at init time the FILEPATH must contain one filter declaration and one filter mapping per core you want to expose

Wherever some admin or servlet or page was referring to the SIMPLECLASSNAME singleton or SIMPLECLASSNAME they now check for the request attribute METHODORVARIABLENAME first the filters set this attribute before forwarding to the other parts
Admin servlet Has been modified to use the core exposed through the request attribute METHODORVARIABLENAME
REPLICATION The feature has not been implemented yet the starting point is that instead of having just one index directory index the naming scheme for the index data directories is index
Have to investigate
FUTURE Uploading new schema conf would be nice allowing Solr to create cores dynamically the upload mechanism itself is easy the servlet dispatch filter needs to be modified
Having replication embedded in the Solr application itself using an http based version of the rsync algorithm some of the core code of jarsync might be handy
MISC The patch production process not as easy as I thought it was with a Windows Netbeans cygwin TortoiseSVN

Initial point is to have the modified code running in a local patch branch all tests ok Have one clean version of the trunk aside the local patch branch you will need to verify that your patch can be applied to the last clean trunk version and that various tests still work from there
Creating the patch is key
If you used some IDE and forgot to set the auto indentation corrrectly you most likely need working around the space indentation patch clutter that results
I could not find a way to get SIMPLECLASSNAME create a patch with the proper options ignore spaces al and could not find a way to get SIMPLECLASSNAME generate one either
Thus I create the patch from the local trunk root through cygwin with svn patchutils svn different different cmd SIMPLECLASSNAME bin different x w B b E d N you solr METHODORVARIABLENAME
Before generating the patch it is important to issue an svn add for each file you might have added a quick svn status grep
allows to verify nothing will be missing
Not elegant but you can even follow with svn status grep
awk print xargs svn add Apply the patch to the clean trunk
SIMPLECLASSNAME apply patch command only understands unified different thus the you option
Alternatively you can apply the patch through cygwin patch p you solr METHODORVARIABLENAME
I have updated the dev environment to an x Solaris box which now generates the zipped patch solr FILEPATH same patch production method

For Solaris users patch must be gnu patch SIMPLECLASSNAME local bin patch is its usual location not to be confused with SIMPLECLASSNAME patch For x you can find it at ftp WEBLINK pub freeware intel patch VERSIONNUMBER sol x METHODORVARIABLENAME I do not know about different but I am using the version located at ftp WEBLINK pub freeware intel diffutils VERSIONNUMBER sol intel METHODORVARIABLENAME

summary: Authorizers not consulted at login
description: From the jspwiki dev list Steve Dahl wrote Under SIMPLECLASSNAME VERSIONNUMBER we have replaced SIMPLECLASSNAME with an SIMPLECLASSNAME which implements SIMPLECLASSNAME roles in terms of LDAP groups

When I compile this for SIMPLECLASSNAME VERSIONNUMBER and modify the METHODORVARIABLENAME file to use it our custom SIMPLECLASSNAME gets initialized and is sent SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME but it never seems to get sent SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME

If it is useful information SIMPLECLASSNAME implements Authorizer not SIMPLECLASSNAME and it implements SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME with this signature public boolean SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME SIMPLECLASSNAME session Principal role Is there anything that has changed in Authorizers between VERSIONNUMBER and VERSIONNUMBER that might explain this
Looking deeper it seems that in SIMPLECLASSNAME VERSIONNUMBER SIMPLECLASSNAME implemented SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME which initialized the session with whatever groups and roles the user belongs to
Groups are read from the group database and Roles are read from the Authorizer
In SIMPLECLASSNAME VERSIONNUMBER SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME has been replaced by SIMPLEMETHODORVARIABLENAME which reads groups from the group database but does not use the Authorizer
What is the Authorizer used for now
As a side note I originally implemented SIMPLECLASSNAME as SIMPLECLASSNAME

I ended up rejecting this approach because SIMPLECLASSNAME assumes that the members of a Group can be read once when the Wiki is started and that the Group s membership will only be modified by the Wiki
The problem with LDAP is that the group membership can be modified from outside and the only way to update the wiki would be to manually restart it
The Authorizer was a better solution for our purposes because if a user was added to the LDAP group the Authorizer would reflect that change as soon as the user logged out and back in
Restarting the wiki is not necessary

summary: Consistent date and time formats
description: This issue was changed to better reflect the initiated discussion Focus is on How SIMPLECLASSNAME are stored internally for example as page content or metadata comments etc
How they are rendered to end users in their browsers The original issue name was Date and time formats according to ISO
We have multiple occurences of hard coded or context unaware SIMPLECLASSNAME to String conversions page properties SIMPLECLASSNAME templates
My proposal is to rely on an international standard instead of using an invented default
The current international standard is ISO s Wikipedia
My further proposal is to show time with the precision to the second as the SI unit system defines the second as the basic unit of time
Furthermore GMT is replaced by UTC and they might differ up to a second s Wikipedia
I think this will make unlocalized strings more transparent to the users and easier to decode correctly consider is it in the future or in the past or might it even be the current time

Following this proposal java format strings allowed for above cases would be Simple date yyyy MM dd The daily mail for was sent Date and time VERSIONNUMBER Explicit time context yyyy MM dd hh mm ssZ User gkarlic made this at VERSIONNUMBER Implicit time context yyyy MM dd hh mm ss This server lives on CET here it is Where VERSIONNUMBER would be used for strings that might emerge from different time zones
If others agree with this proposal I would gladly make the required changes

summary: Separate rendering engine from core
description: Quite a few people have shown up recently on the mailing list and have expressed a wish to separate the rendering engine from the core itself so that they would not need so much baggage with the engine

Unfortunately this is quite difficult as the rendering engine does rely on quite a few bits from the SIMPLECLASSNAME instance for example URL generation and checking whether a page attachment exists or not as well as settings
However these things could be enumerated and isolated to a SIMPLECLASSNAME interface
Then anyone who would like to get their own engine would need to implement this interface
It may mean that SIMPLECLASSNAME and SIMPLECLASSNAME might need to become interfaces as well
However that might not be such a bad thing as it would give a more stable developer API

Then we would have a three layered architecture where one layer WikiEngine takes care of static stuff SIMPLECLASSNAME contains per request data and SIMPLECLASSNAME provides the bits and pieces which are part of HTML generation
At any rate this requires more thinking
Probably not going to happen before VERSIONNUMBER anyway

IE still has a market share but it is waning
